name: Persona Critique
description: Evaluate an idea or decision from the perspective of a specific user, stakeholder, or archetype to uncover blind spots, unmet needs, or misaligned incentives.
output_instructions: Write 3 short observations from the viewpoint of a key user or stakeholder. Highlight one unmet need, one incentive misalignment, and one overlooked expectation.

name: Systems Thinking
description: Analyze how components interact within a whole system, focusing on feedback loops, dependencies, and second-order effects rather than isolated parts.
output_instructions: Identify 3 system-level effects or feedback loops. Mention one upstream or downstream impact the idea could trigger unintentionally.

name: Good Enough Solution Analysis (GESA)
description: Determine the minimum viable solution that adequately solves the problem, avoiding over-engineering and optimizing for speed, cost, or practicality.
output_instructions: List 3 ways the idea might be overbuilt or more complex than necessary. Suggest one simpler approach that could achieve 80% of the desired outcome faster or cheaper.

name: Constraint Analysis
description: Identify and examine limiting factors (time, budget, skills, regulations, resources) to shape realistic solutions and prioritize leverage points.
output_instructions: Point out 3 realistic constraints that might be ignored. For each, explain how it could block or distort the idea’s execution.

name: Opposing Viewpoint
description: Deliberately argue against your own position to stress-test reasoning, expose weaknesses, and reduce confirmation bias.
output_instructions: Write a short paragraph arguing against the idea from a skeptical viewpoint. Focus on what could go wrong, why it might fail, or what assumption it relies on too heavily.

name: Category Error Check
description: Verify that concepts, metrics, or solutions are being applied to the correct type of problem, preventing mismatches between problem class and approach.
output_instructions: Ask: Is the idea solving the right type of problem (e.g., technical vs. behavioral)? Mention 2 signs of mismatch between problem type and approach.

name: Root Cause Analysis
description: Trace symptoms back to their underlying causes—often using methods like the '5 Whys'—to ensure solutions address the source, not just effects.
output_instructions: List the observed problem and ask 'why' iteratively to surface 2 plausible root causes. End with a sentence on whether the idea targets the root or a symptom.

name: First Principles Decomposition
description: Break a problem down to fundamental truths and rebuild solutions from the ground up, avoiding assumptions inherited from precedent or convention.
output_instructions: Briefly list 3 assumptions baked into the idea. Propose how rethinking one from first principles might yield a simpler or stronger alternative.

name: Assumption Testing
description: Explicitly surface assumptions and validate them through data, experiments, or counterexamples before committing to decisions.
output_instructions: List 3 assumptions the idea depends on. For each, assess if it’s validated or not — and note one way it could be tested quickly.

name: Opportunity Cost Assessment
description: Evaluate what is being sacrificed by choosing one option over others, ensuring resources are allocated to the highest-value alternative.
output_instructions: Briefly describe 2 other paths that won’t be pursued if this idea is chosen. Mention what potential value could be left on the table.
